description: Erection of hip to gable and rear dormer roof extensions and installation of 2 no. rooflights to front roofslope
decision_conditions: The proposed erection of hip to gable and rear dormer roof extensions and installation of 2 no. rooflights to front roofslope falls within the parameters of permitted development as set out under Schedule 2, Part 1, Class B & Class C of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as amended).

Application SiteThe site comprises a single storey commercial property with a two storey residential dwelling to the rear within the Oakhill Conservation Area (A). The special architectural and historic interest of this area can be summarised as: A Regency and early Victorian linear housing development made up of two separate areas Oakhill Conservation Area (A) which runs along the old turnpike road of Ewell Road and Oakhill Conservation Area (B) which is made up of five large properties in Langley Road. The area around Ewell Road was later converted to a commercial centre, together with an area of substantial Victorian houses and The Wood open space to the west.Consultation11 Neighbouring properties have been notified and no representations have been received.Surbiton CAAC - No objection.AssessmentThe application relates to the display of advertisements. The key considerations are -Character and Appearance/Amenity-Public safetyCharacter and Appearance/AmenityThe signage would be on the front of the building and would be internally illuminated. All signs and fascias in conservation areas should be externally illuminated with spot or trough lighting as internally illuminated signs often detract from the visual amenity of an area. In this case, the proposed signage would replace externally lit advertisement with an internally lit advertisement which would be at odds with much of the neighbouring advertisements.It is therefore considered that the proposed internally illuminated fascia would not be a sympathetic addition to the  shop frontage of the host property and would detract from its character and appearance and the surrounding Conservation Area.Public safetyThe proposed signage would be static and would not obscure any highway signs or impede pedestrian movement. The proposed signage would not prejudice highway safety. ConclusionIn conclusion the proposed signage would accord with policies D3 of the London Plan 2021 and CS8 and DM10 of the Council's adopted LDF Core Strategy.
